document_metadata.name: Pathogenic forms of tau inhibit kinesin-dependent axonal transport through a mechanism involving activation of axonal phosphotransferases.

citation.db_name: Pathogenic forms of tau inhibit kinesin-dependent axonal transport through a mechanism involving activation of axonal phosphotransferases.
citation.journal: The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience

links.evidence: perfusion of full-length WT tau monomers (2 􏰊M) (Fig. 1 A) had no effect on FAT in squid axoplasm (Fig. 2 A), while 6D and 6P tau monomers (2 􏰊M) significantly inhibited anterograde FAT when compared with WT tau monomer (Fig. 2 B, C) or buffer controls (data not shown).

links.evidence: Together, these data demonstrate that, as posited for aggregated tau (LaPointe et al., 2009), short N-terminal isoforms of tau inhibit anterograde FAT by a mechanism involving activation of PP1 and GSK3 that is independent of microtubule binding.

citation.db_name: Pathogenic forms of tau inhibit kinesin-dependent axonal transport through a mechanism involving activation of axonal phosphotransferases.
citation.journal: The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience

links.evidence: Soluble AT8 tau monomers inhibited anterograde FAT (Fig. 6 A, C), while retrograde trans- port was unaffected (Fig. 6 A, D). These data indicate that phosphorylation of tau at the AT8 epitope, which is associated with hyperphosphorylation of tau in AD and other tauopathies, renders soluble monomeric tau capable of inhibiting antero- grade FAT.
